Articles.Content: I have gone to the mun and Minmus and have a mobile base on the mun and I want to go to Duna next. Any tips? What about Ike? Should I go to Duna and Ike in one rocket or separate?

Ike doesn't require much Delta-V to intercept and land with, as well as take off. If you're not doing any docking, you definitely should try to compact your vessel enough to where your Delta-V usage is at peak efficiency.

Now if you're landing on Duna as well, it may be a good idea to bring a supplement lander as a backup in case of calculation "errors".

And I tried the docking tutorial and I spent like 30 minutes doing the attachment to the other ship. How could I do this better? And should I be using docking mode cause I did it with the rcs controls which was annoying and I kept missing the docking portand having to back up.

Personally, I find that Docking Mode is much harder for some reason.

It's difficult to give a verdict without knowing your orbital parameters, but let's run through the book just to be safe.

The rocket design should have RCS blocks as far away from the center of mass as they can. This is because the center of mass is also the center of rotation.

Target the docking port on the other vessel, line up your own before moving in [to make rotary changes as you see fit], then translate forward quickly, and gradually decelerate as you get closer. This is so that the target wont have much time to deviate off center, thus wasting time on radial and normal translations.

...Oh, you already knew? Well shoot... I guess the answer would just be practice. Docking IS one of the more difficult objectives in the game.
